holidays.name: Buy Nothing Day
holidays.description: A day dedicated to anti-consumerism and encouraging people to abstain from purchasing anything for 24 hours as a protest against overconsumption.
holidays.origin: Started in Canada in 1992 by artist Ted Dave and the Adbusters magazine as a response to Black Friday shopping frenzy.
holidays.funFact: Buy Nothing Day is intentionally placed on the day after Thanksgiving in the U.S., the biggest shopping day of the year, to make a bold statement.

holidays.name: Blasé Day
holidays.description: A quirky celebration recognizing people who approach everything with a blasé, indifferent attitude, embracing cool nonchalance in a hectic world.
holidays.origin: Informal and unofficial—celebrated mostly by internet communities who love sarcastic and ironic holidays.
holidays.funFact: Blasé Day encourages wearing sunglasses indoors and shrugging off all responsibilities, just for one day.

holidays.name: Parfait Day
holidays.description: A delicious day to celebrate the layered dessert known as parfait, featuring yogurt, fruit, granola, and sweet toppings.
holidays.origin: Originating from the French word meaning 'perfect,' Parfait Day is a fun food holiday to honor this elegant treat.
holidays.funFact: Traditional French parfaits are usually frozen desserts, but many Americans think of the parfait as a layered yogurt treat!

holidays.name: World TV Day
holidays.description: An international observance recognizing the impact of television on decision-making by bringing attention to major issues such as globalization and cultural exchanges via TV.
holidays.origin: Established by the United Nations in 1996 to recognize television's role in communication and information dissemination.
holidays.funFact: November 25 was chosen because the first World Summit on Television occurred on that date in 1996.
